title: 105_hr4240
content: The Act is titled the "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" and addresses liability for computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" addresses liability for computer date failure in cases where only contract-based recovery for business losses and repair costs is allowed if certain conditions are met, excluding personal injury claims. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires notifying buyers of computer system components experiencing date failure, offering free repairs for products sold after December 31, 1994. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" mandates notifying buyers of computer system components with date failure issues and providing free repairs for products sold after December 31, 1994. The notice must specify the affected system or component and explain how buyers can obtain repairs. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires sellers to inform buyers about computer system components with date failure issues and provide free repairs for products sold after December 31, 1994. Buyers must be informed about how to obtain repairs or replacements for the affected system components or software. This subsection does not limit the ability of parties to enter into agreements regarding liability and damages resulting from computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires sellers to inform buyers about computer system components with date failure issues and provide free repairs for products sold after December 31, 1994. Parties can enter into agreements on liability and damages from computer date failure. In cases not covered by the Act, actions against a person due to computer date failure are contract-based, allowing recovery for business loss and repair costs if no personal injury is involved. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" allows for liability agreements and damages related to computer date failure, provided certain conditions are met. These conditions include no personal injury to the plaintiff and the defendant making efforts to prevent date failure. Testing systems for Y2K compliance by simulating the transition is also required. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires companies to test their systems by simulating the transition to the Year 2000 and provide notice of their compliance efforts by August 1, 1999. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" mandates companies to test systems for Year 2000 compliance and post a notice of their efforts by August 1, 1999. The President's Council on the Year 2000 Conversion will share this notice on its website. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" requires companies to test for Year 2000 compliance and post a notice on the Council's website. This does not limit parties from making agreements on liability and damages from computer date failures. Definitions include actions for damages from computer date failures and the term "computer date failure." The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" mandates testing for Year 2000 compliance and posting notices on the Council's website. It allows agreements on liability and damages from computer date failures. The term "computer date failure" refers to issues with storing, processing, or exchanging data between the years 1999 and 2000. The term "computer program or software" refers to a set of instructions used in a computer to achieve a specific result. A "computer system" includes electronic devices, networks, and embedded chips that perform functions like logic, arithmetic, data processing, and communication. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY ANTITRUST EXEMPTION. Antitrust laws do not apply to conduct aimed at addressing computer date failure until December 31, 2001, except in cases of boycott. The term "antitrust laws" is defined as per the Clayton Act. The term "antitrust laws" as defined in the Clayton Act includes section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act and any similar State laws.
